 newbie question... how do all the ships propulsion work???

how do all the races ships (goa'uld, Asgard, sg-1's promethous) propulsion work?? Is it warp drive or wormholes or what?? Was it explained how they travel faster than light??
And do all the races have the same propulsion systems??

thanks.

The Keeper

There are 2 kinds of engines in a lot of sci-fi:
- Sublight engines
- Hyper Drives

The first is sort of like a rocket propulsion system, and the second involves using a machine that bends space-time around the vessel, and the ship goes into a fake wormhole.
That's my understanding of it, feel free to pick it apart!!

The Keeper

Rhydderch Hael
The Radiation King

Registered: Oct 2001
Location: On station at a distant underground nuclear missile silo...
Posts: 1816

The propulsion of most Goa'uld ships at sublight velocity is by inertial displacement (or repulsor-drive, or anti-gravity, whatever you want to call it). One type of Goa'uld ship, the Alkesh (seen in the season 4 finale "Exodus") has "rocket"-type reaction motors. It's the one exception we've seen so far.+

Faster-than-light travel is caused by punching a subspace window that allows the craft to jump into hyperspace. Basically, 'tis a mix of both Star Trek and Babylon 5 terminology and concepts.

If my explanation is fuzzy and vague, don't worry about it—because the TV show itself is fuzzy and vague about the matter!

Stargate has been, and should always be, about traveling to strange and amazing alien worlds on foot.

__________________

Well, I have my onw explanation about the Goa'uld subspace propulsion, even for the Al-Kesh.

The ships self apply some sort of electro-magnetic field that propels them.

That's all.

Lord ?kar

Registered: Aug 2002

Posts: 621

The Alkesh is the only ship that doesnt use the inertial gravity field propusion system that we've seen on all other Goa'uld vessels. Four nacelles at the rear of the craft.

Faster-than-light travel is caused by punching a subspace window that allows the craft to jump into hyperspace.
It just tears a hole in space-time to hyperspace. That is surpisingly similar to the description of a wormhole. I'm not sure if the window shuts behind the ship or what.
